results.title: 1900: Age of hope. 1914: Killing fields. 1917: Red flag
results.creator_credit: BBC, WGBH (Boston), Jonathan Lewis and Bill Treharne Jones
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “People’s century: 1900-1999”.
This tape contains the first three episodes of the ‘People’s century 1900-1999’ series. “1900: age of hope”; as the century begins, a trade exhibition in Paris captures the optimism of the new century as the powerful countries of the world showcase their material progress. The state funeral of Queen Victoria in 1901 undermines progress however, reminding the country of its ties with the old order of European dynasties. Russia too is caught firmly in the grip of autocracy, leading many Europeans to migrate to America. Mass literacy vastly changes the political awareness of ordinary citizens and newspapers bring politics to the masses in Britain and the United States. The suffragette movement is also in full swing, while the colonies work towards self government. Europe is caught up in strategic alliances, a situation which ensures world involvement should a war begin. Narrated by Sean Barrett. “1914: killing fields”; Europe and Germany are drawn into a new kind of war - an industrialized war in which logistics and machine guns make a devastating and significant debut. There is the first full scale project of propaganda against the Germans, as battles at the Somme, Verdun and Ypres facilitate the slaughter of thousands of soldiers on both sides of the battle. The war ends in 1918 with an armistice and no clear victor, as well as a new distrust of public figureheads who allowed the slaughter to continue. It seems doubtful the world can return to the idyll of 1914. Narrated by Veronica Hyks. “917: red flag”; in the Soviet Union the people finally make a move to overthrown the tsar, Nicholas II, and put an end to autocratic power. An uprising, led by the Marxist socialist Lenin succeeds in overthrowing the tsar and his family. He replaces it with another system which would have international repercussion, Communism, which appealed to America during the Depression due to its productivity and opportunities for women. Narrated by Sean Barrett.

results.title: 1900 = Novecento = Millenovecento [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Artemis Productions, Les Productions Artistes Associes, Produzioni Europee Associati, Alberto Grimaldi and Bernardo Bertolucci
results.brief_description: On the eve of the new twentieth century two young boys are born on the same estate in northern Italy. Olmo is the bastard son of the peasants who work the land; Alfredo is the landowner’s child. Initially friends as boys, when Olmo and Alfredo become adults (played respectively by Gerard Depardieu and Robert de Niro), they find that the stark differences of class, status and politics estrange them from one another. Olmo becomes a Communist and is involved in revolutionary politics. Alfredo finds himself drawn into fascism, even as his bohemian wife (Dominique Sanda) finds herself increasingly horrified by the excesses of the fascist thugs. Bertolucci’s vivid baroque epic dramatises the tumultuous history of modern Italy through the personal struggles of the two men. This is an epic dedicated to the European working-classes, but at the film’s centre there is a contradiction between Bertolucci’s avowed aim to make a populist epic spectacle and his intellectual and ethical commitment to dense Marxist aesthetics and polemics. If the film itself never comfortably overcomes this contradiction, lurching from intimate poetic scenes of friendship and betrayal to vulgar and vivid gothic grand guignol (in particular scenes featuring Donald Sutherland and Laura Betti as a perverse sado-masochistic fascist couple) what is undeniable are the resonances and captivating beauty of Bertolucci’s epic vision: at times it is as if he wishes to distill the essence of time, history and revolution in his mise-en-scene. What also remains unforgettable is the rich depth of the characters in this film. Depardieu and de Niro both give heroic performances, as does Sterling Hayden and Burt Lancaster as the respective patriarchal heads of the peasantry and of the landowners. Apart from being a dialectician’s‘s epic about class struggle and Italian history, “1900” is also one of cinema’s most tender explorations of the complexities and love involved in friendship. This mad, confused sweeping saga finally climaxes with an imagined re-writing of history where Communism liberates forever the peasant and working classes of Italy. But for all the ludicrous impossibility and naivety of this climax, the film ends on a note of sublime transcendence. This is classic epic cinema re-imagined by a Marxist poet. The musical score is by Enno Morricone. The ravishing cinematography by Vittorio Storaro. In Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: 1893-1901: early Edison films
results.brief_description: A compilation of 19 Thomas Edison films, some made for use in kinetoscopes others for public projection, averaging less than one minute each. Most are single shot films except ‘McKinley’s Inauguration’ and ‘Admiral Dewey at Manila Bay’ which are made up of several shots. Includes “Washing the Baby” (1893) and “Inauguration of President McKinley” (1896) and what is regarded as the first advertising film.

results.brief_description: NARRATED IN FRENCH. NO ENGLISH SUBTITLES. Uses drawings and contemporary engravings by Daumier, Gauarni, Decamps and others to depict the period of the 1848 Revolution in France. Examines the causes for discontent as the monarchy totters, the fierce street fighting that precipitated its downfall, and finally the election of Louis Napoleon and the celebration of the new freedom - and the betrayal of that freedom.

results.brief_description: The twenty-third world championship match for builders of free-flight model aircraft, held at Goteborg, Sweden, in July 1971, in which a Canadian team competed. results.title: 150 to the acre
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), James Allen, Jean Hunt, Murray Brown and Robert Newton
results.brief_description: Discusses the problems arising from living in high-rise developments. These include high noise-levels and lack of playing-space for children. An architect shows plans for high-density housing which should overcome these problems while still providing housing for many people in relatively small areas. Set in Melbourne, Victoria. Narrated by Wynn Roberts. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.

results.title: 15 Amore
results.creator_credit: MTXM Movies, Maurice Murphy and Brooke Wilson
results.brief_description: Based on the director/writer’s own childhood experiences, this period drama is set in an idyllic rural Australia during World War II when two Italian POW’s, a Jewish German woman and her daughter are billeted with a farmer’s wife and her three children on an isolated farmstead. Told from the point-of-view of a young boy, the daily existence of the characters as they grow closer to one another, seems harmonious and carefree. Yet beneath this tranquility simmers war- induced trauma, fear and cynicism which inevitably erupts. A perceptive look at cultural difference, this beautifully photographed film avoids slipping into nostalgia and stereotype by staying focused on the characters’ motivations and conflicting emotional states. Cast: Lisa Hensley, Steve Bastoni, Domenic Galati, Tara Jakszewicz, Gertrude Ingeborg, Rhianna Griffith, Bill Hunter. Photography by John Borck. Music by Carlo Giacco.

results.title: 15' Zondergrond = 15' Metromania = 15 Metromania
results.creator_credit: Bart Van den Bempt and Bert Hamelinck
results.brief_description: Bernd is the new security guard at the Metro underground. Just as he relaxes into the position, a stern boss dictates some impossible rules and young Bernd’s day goes from bad to worse. Drawing on the aesthetic of the surveillance industry, director Bart Van den Bempt parallels surveillance type images alongside the running plot with split screens. As Bernd, infatuation by a young woman, tracks her movements using the security cameras, we the audience tour the process of security camera surveillance. The film style and structure become bound to the processes of surveillance, whilst the process of surveillance informs the film structure (specifically the narrative and the editing style).
